availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: The manuscript leaf is glued to a backing sheet, making the verso inaccessible.
This manuscript was likely composed in the fall of 1888 and certainly not before 1884, as the Century Magazine article for which this is a draft appeared in October 1888.

revisionDesc.change: moved list of persons responsible to titleStmt

body.note: follow copy punctuation &c after reading first proof by copy, & correcting, please send me a good second proof. & send copy with it— address Walt Whitman 328 Mickle street, Camden, New Jersey.
body.head: Army Hospitals and Cases.
Memoranda at the time—1863–'6.
body.note: put brackets at beginning & close of this ¶
body.p: [Of reminiscences of the Secession War, after the rest is said, it remains to give a few special words—in some respects the typical words of all, and the most definitive—of the Army Hospitals, and samples of those that filled them, of the Killed and wounded in action, and the cases of those soldiers who lingered afterward from these wounds, or soldiers were laid up by disease or prostration. The general statistics have perhaps been printed already in this Magazine, but, as introductory to these Hospital the incidents I am going to describe, can bear to be briefly stated again.

p.transpose: There were over 3,000,000 men, (for all periods of enlistment, large and small) furnished to the Union Army during the war.
